Issues.Title: fix(language-service): prevent interpolation from superseding block bâ€¦
Issues.Body:
â€¦races

This change omits the injection of the template syntaxes inside any existing block scope. The injection is not needed because the template and expression scopes are included explicitly as patterns where appropriate under the template-blocks definitions.

This change prevents the interpolation curly braces from superseding the match for the open curly of the block body. This issue also happens with ICUs (#62697), but those do not have any named scopes to exclude as of today.

fixes https://github.com/angular/vscode-ng-language-service/issues/1991
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(language-service): prevent interpolation from superseding block bâ€¦" (#64392)

Issues.Title: Signal Form disabled() method sets disable instead of disabled attribute (v21.0.0-next.7)
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

Description

When using the Signal Form API in Angular v21.0.0-next.7, calling the disabled() method does not actually disable the input field.

The underlying issue appears to be that the generated HTML attribute is disable instead of disabled.

Reproduction

[StackBlitz reproduction link](https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-xxzqechu?file=src%2Fmain.ts)

Steps to Reproduce

Open the StackBlitz link above.

Click on the password input field.

Type any characters â€” the field is still editable even though it should be disabled.

Expected Behavior

The password input field should be disabled and not accept any input after calling the disabled() method.

Actual Behavior

The password input remains editable.
Inspecting the DOM shows that the attribute is rendered as disable instead of disabled.

Environment

Angular version: 21.0.0-next.7

Browser: Chrome (latest)

Operating System: macOS

Reproduction link: [StackBlitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-xxzqechu?file=src%2Fmain.ts)

Additional Context

This seems to be a regression in the Signal Form API introduced in Angular v21.
The issue may be related to the internal handling of the disabled property binding in signal-based form controls.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-xxzqechu?file=src%2Fmain.ts

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true

```

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI       : 21.0.0-next.7
Angular           : 21.0.0-next.7
Node.js           : 20.19.2
```

Issues.Title: Establish and implement a cross-framework interoperability standard for Angular, React, and other SPAs
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

As modern enterprises increasingly go through mergers and acquisitions, integrating UI applications built with different SPA frameworks (e.g., Angular, React, Vue) has become a frequent challenge.

In such scenarios, the acquiring company and the acquired company often use different front-end stacks, and the immediate business goal is to integrate both applications quicklyâ€”usually before backend systems are merged. This is done to give customers a unified experience under a single domain and accelerate go-to-market objectives.

However, when these applications are built using different frameworks, ensuring runtime stability, routing consistency, and isolation becomes extremely difficult.

This is particularly important for Angular-based applications, since React is currently the most widely used SPA framework. As a result, Angular applications are more likely to need to coexist with React apps during integration phases. Angular developers face the dual challenge of integrating quickly while guaranteeing that Angular code cannot, under any circumstance, destabilize the parent React application.

Currently, there is no standard or official contract that defines how multiple SPA frameworks can safely run together within the same browser window or page. This lack of guidance leads to uncertainty, trial-and-error approaches, and potential instability in production environments.

### Proposed solution

I propose that the Angular team define, document, and implement an official interop contract for running Angular alongside other SPA frameworksâ€”especially Reactâ€”in the same browser instance.

This initiative could focus on establishing clear stability guarantees and best practices for framework coexistence, potentially serving as the foundation for a broader industry-wide standard.

Key areas to address:

Runtime stability: Ensure Angular and React can operate concurrently without global side effects or conflicts (e.g., DOM events, polyfills).

Router isolation and synchronization: Define how both frameworks can manage or isolate routing and browser history state cleanly.

Context sharing: Establish safe and standardized ways to share context (e.g., user session, theme, i18n) between frameworks.

Sandbox boundaries: Clarify how Angularâ€™s internalsâ€”signals, change detection, stylesâ€”can be sandboxed or encapsulated when coexisting with other frameworks.

Interop checklist: Provide a checklist or diagnostic tool to validate a safe integration setup.

Reference architecture: Publish a working sample or starter template demonstrating Reactâ€“Angular coexistence using best practices.

I am willing to contribute engineering effort from my company to collaborate on this feature, should the Angular team choose to lead this effort.

### Alternatives considered

Yes, several approaches exist, but none fully solve the interop or stability challenges:

- Web Components â€“ Provide DOM and style encapsulation but no runtime isolation. Framework-level conflicts (e.g., routing, context) still occur.

- Micro-frontend frameworks (e.g., Module Federation, single-spa) â€“ Enable framework integration, but without guarantees around stability or isolation.

- Zoneless Angular with Signals â€“ Promising in reducing reactivity overhead, but lacks a formalized interop contract with other SPAs.

- Full rewrite to React â€“ Sometimes considered for compatibility, but this is costly, time-consuming, and unnecessary if Angular could safely coexist.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Establish and implement a cross-framework interoperability standard for Angular, React, and other SPAs" (#64378)

Issues.Title: fix(core): control not recognized when input has directive injecting ViewContainerRef
Issues.Body:
When a directive injects a `ViewContainerRef`, the runtime inserts a container that was throwing off the logic that recognizes native controls.

These changes switch to check if the node is a native control through the `TNode`. This also makes it a bit less prone to breaking during SSR.

Fixes #64362.

Issues.Title: build(@angular/build): update vitest to v4.0.0-beta
Issues.Body:
This commit updates the version of `vitest` and its related packages from `3.2.4` to `4.0.0-beta.17` within the unit testing system.

This major version update for Vitest introduces several changes that are addressed here:
- The `coverage.all` option has been removed in Vitest v4. Accordingly, the `coverageAll` option has been removed from the unit-test builders schema and its usage has been removed from the Karma and Vitest test runner implementations.
- The browser provider mechanism has been updated. Vitest now uses provider-specific packages (e.g., `@vitest/browser-playwright`) instead of the general `@vitest/browser` package. The browser configuration setup has been made asynchronous and now dynamically loads the appropriate provider.
- A workaround has been added to filter non-string values from the resolved coverage exclude patterns. This prevents an error caused by Vitest incorrectly adding boolean values into the array.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build(@angular/build): update vitest to v4.0.0-beta" (#31452)

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): add matcher transformations to jasmine-to-vitest schematic
Issues.Body:
This commit adds transformers for a wide range of Jasmine matchers.

Coverage includes:
- Syntactic sugar matchers (toBeTrue, toHaveSize, etc.)
- Asymmetric matchers (jasmine.any, jasmine.objectContaining)
- Async matchers (expectAsync)
- Complex structural rewrites for matchers like `toHaveBeenCalledOnceWith` and `arrayWithExactContents`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@schematics/angular): add matcher transformations to jasmine-to-vitest schematic" (#31448)

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): introduce initial jasmine-to-vitest unit test refactor schematic
Issues.Body:
This commit introduces the base infrastructure for an experimental jasmine-to-vitest refactoring schematic and the initial set of transformers for lifecycle functions.

The base infrastructure includes the main schematic entry point, the AST transformer driver, and various utilities for AST manipulation, validation, and reporting.

The lifecycle transformers handle:
- fdescribe/fit -> describe.only/it.only
- xdescribe/xit -> describe.skip/it.skip
- pending() -> it.skip()
- Asynchronous tests using the 'done' callback are converted to 'async/await'.

Usage:
`ng generate jasmine-to-vitest [--project <project-name>]`

serve

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

This bug was presented in followings https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/15116 and https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/15211 but actually the fix seems not work as shown in the repro available here

https://github.com/devel0/repros/tree/angular/cli-basehref

Issues.Title: feat(@angular/build): support `.test.ts` files by default in unit test builder
Issues.Body:
The unit test discovery logic previously had hardcoded conventions for `.spec.ts` files. This made it inflexible for projects that use other common patterns, such as `.test.ts`.

This change introduces support for `.test.ts` files by default and refactors the discovery logic to be more flexible and maintainable.

Key changes:
- The `unit-test` builder schema now includes both `**/*.spec.ts` and `**/*.test.ts` in its default `include` globs.
- The internal test discovery logic in `test-discovery.ts` is refactored to use a configurable array of test file infixes (`.spec`, `.test`).
- This allows the smart-handling of static paths (e.g., `ng test --include src/app/app.component.ts`) to correctly resolve the corresponding test file for both conventions.
- JSDoc comments and variable names have been updated to improve clarity and reflect the new, more flexible approach.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(@angular/build): support `.test.ts` files by default in unit test builder" (#31438)

Issues.Title: Setting CI=true causes Angular 20 builds to fail with exit code -1073740940 on Windows

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

We recently upgraded our application from Angular 19 to 20. When we run a build on our Windows Jenkins server, our angular library fails to build and npm exits with error "-1073740940". When we run local it builds as expected.

I have tracked this down to Jenkins automatically setting the environment variable "CI" to true. I can reproduce the same error by setting the environment variable CI to true. I have yet to see the same error with CI not set or set to false.

I have tried multiple versions of both Node (21.9.5, 22.20.0) and NPM (10.9.3, 11.6.2) and get the same behavior.

### Command

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Yarn recently introduced `npmMinimalAgeGate` which prevents downloading npm packages that are newer than the specified age. If using it and trying to install packages using `ng update` it just fails without any clear reason. What I would expect to happen is that `ng update` would list and download available packages while respecting the `npmMinimalAgeGate`, or at the very least the error could be made more descriptive.

Issues.Title: build: refactor ng_package substitutions
Issues.Body:
This refactoring moves the substitution for `@angular/ssr` and `beasties` from a global configuration to a local one within the `@angular/ssr` package definition.

This is achieved by introducing an `extra_substitutions` parameter to the `ng_package` function, allowing package-specific substitutions to be defined. This change improves modularity and removes hardcoded paths from the global substitution rules, making the build system cleaner and easier to maintain.

Additionally, this fixes an issue where the generated TypeScript definition files (.d.ts) for `@angular/ssr` had incorrect relative paths for the `beasties` dependency, causing type resolution failures in consuming projects. The new local substitution corrects these paths.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: refactor ng_package substitutions" (#31434)

Issues.Title: @angular/build:unit-test: Launching ng test --include with Windows path fails
Issues.Body:
### Command

test

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

This issue is specific to Windows and launching ng test with a specific file. Vitest is configured as the test runner.

1. Building tests works but running tests fails with the error: "No test files found." if you launch ng test with a Windows path:
```
ng test --browsers Chromium --include "C:\client\src\app\header\header.component.spec.ts"
```

2. Building and running tests work if you launch ng test with a quasi-POSIX path on Windows:
```
ng test --browsers Chromium --include "C:/client/src/app/header/header.component.spec.ts"
```

3. Building tests fails if you launch ng test with a full POSIX path on Windows:
```
ng test --browsers Chromium --include "/c/client/src/app/header/header.component.spec.ts"
```

Since the native Windows path is not working, you can't use ${file} in launch.json of Visual Studio Code. Similarly, the full POSIX path ${command:extension.commandvariable.file.filePosix}" is not working either. This prevents the launching of the current test file on Windows.

Reproduced with 21.0.0-next.7

Issues.Title: [reopen] ng serve does not recognize "Accept: */*" header and returns a 404 for requests with route fragments
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Currently playwright sends `Accept: */*` header, and receive 404 error. I reopened #12613, since it is still relevant.

### Minimal Reproduction

Run playwright test, that loading angular dev server page.

```typescript
it('test', async ({page}) => {
  await page.goTo('http://localhost:4200');
});
```

Issues.Title: bug(MatList, IconButton): IconButton with matListItemMeta renders incorrectly for multiline mat list items
Issues.Body: ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description Adding an IconButton with `matListItemMeta` directive into the multine list item causes incorrect rendering of the hover shadow (see the screeshot attached) ``` Incorrect Trailing Icon 1 Second line Third line ``` ### Reproduction StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/hexovpvm?file=src%2Fexample%2Flist-variants-example.html,src%2Fexample%2Flist-variants-example.ts&startScript=start Steps to reproduce: 1. Hover over the IconButton next to the first two list items. Notice, that the icon isn't centered 2. Hover over the IconButton next to the last list item. Notice, that in case of one-line list items the icon is rendered correctly ### Expected Behavior The icon should always be centered inside hover shadow ### Actual Behavior The icon isn't centered inside hover shadow ### Environment - Angular: 20.2.8 - CDK/Material: 20 - Browser(s): chrome - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS

Issues.Title: feat(CdkConnectedOverlay): Expose current position
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

`CdkConnectedOverlay`'s positioning is controlled through `@Input('cdkConnectedOverlayPositions') positions: ConnectedPosition[]`. But, there is no way to know which `ConnectedPosition` is currently applied.

I propose to create a new public parameter in class  `CdkConnectedOverlay` named `currentPosition`, preferably a `signal` which will return the current `ConnectedPosition` which is applied to `CdkConnectedOverlay`

### Use Case

Having access to current `ConnectedPosition` will allow users to

1. Style the panels effectively, like showing an arrow pointing towards it's trigger
2. Animate panels effectively, like using `translate` CSS properties
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(CdkConnectedOverlay): Expose current position" (#32059)

Issues.Title: feat(cdkDrag): Restrict drag movement by individual boundary sides (top, right, bottom, left)
Issues.Body: ### Feature Description **Description:** Introduce a configuration option for `cdkDrag` that allows developers to restrict dragging beyond specific sides of a boundary container. This would enable more nuanced control than the current `cdkDragBoundary`, which enforces containment uniformly on all sides. **Proposed API (example):** ### Use Case **1. MatDialog Handle Visibility Constraint** Enable users to drag a MatDialog freely within a grid layout, but restrict movement beyond the top and left/right edges of the viewport to ensure the dialogâ€™s drag handle remains visible and accessible. This prevents scenarios where users accidentally drag the dialog off-screen, making it difficult or impossible to reposition without refreshing the page or resetting the layout. - Preserves usability by keeping the drag handle within reach. - Prevents frustration from dialogs becoming â€œlostâ€ off-screen. - Supports responsive design by adapting to dynamic viewport sizes. **2. Dashboard Layout Editors** Allow users to drag widgets freely within a grid but prevent them from overlapping fixed headers or sidebars. For example: - Restrict dragging above the top edge to preserve a sticky toolbar. - Allow overflow on the bottom for expandable panels. **3. Mobile UI Builders** In mobile layout editors, you might want to: - Prevent dragging past the left/right edges to maintain responsive design. - Allow vertical overflow for scrollable content zones. **4. Game Interfaces** In drag-based puzzle or strategy games: - Restrict dragging outside the playfield on specific sides (e.g., prevent dragging off the top to simulate gravity). - Allow dragging into inventory zones only from certain directions. **5. Design Tools (e.g., Canva-style editors)** Enable asymmetric drag zones: - Prevent dragging elements off the canvas on the left and top (to preserve alignment). - Allow overflow on the right for snapping to guides or external panels. **6. Workflow Builders / Flowchart Editors** When building visual workflows: - Restrict dragging nodes above the top boundary to avoid overlapping with global controls. - Allow dragging below for expanding the flow. **7. Accessibility-Driven Interfaces** For users with motor impairments: - Restrict dragging to safe zones to prevent accidental loss of visibility. - Customize side restrictions based on user preferences or device orientation.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(cdkDrag): Restrict drag movement by individual boundary sides (top, right, bottom, left)" (#32044)

Issues.Title: docs-bug(all): Improvement suggestion: style docs to emphasize integrity of each method
Issues.Body: ### Documentation Feedback Hi Angular Material Team! This is a suggestion to improve the styling of your generated documentation -- particularly the "API" pages. Something I've noticed over the years is that the API pages are a bit hard to read. In particular, the styling of those pages make it difficult to identify individual methods, and to understand which information to associate with which method. (Context: I just spent a fair amount of time debugging something related to `flexibleDimensions` on the CDKOverlay, and better/more easily intelligible docs would have definitely helped.) My suggestion is to make simple tweaks to your styles that emphasize the boundaries between relevant units of functionality (e.g. method, class, etc), rather than using CSS borders to separate the key/label and value/description in bit of documentation about the unit of functionality. Here's an example of what I am talking about -- the first screenshot is the page now, and the second is what happens if you give the table for each method its own background color and border, and remove the inner borders. (3 CSS property change) All of a sudden users can actually distinguish the individual methods, and you can also see that there is no documentation for `detach`. Lots more could be done with spacing, color, and typography, but this is intended as either a quick win/low-hanging fruit suggestion, or more realistically, an issue to add to your evidence pile that the docs could use some redesign with an eye towards information hierarchy in a future release. --- ### Affected documentation page all pages

Issues.Title: Angular Material changes behaviour without a version change
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Angular Material has changed behaviour multiple times without updating its version in the application where it is used (not doing a single `npm install`, using exactly the same version). Specifically, using @angular/material@20.2.7, MatDrawer has changed from not having an animation to having it multiple times:

- Did not have animation at some point before 06/10/2025 (don't remember the exact date, in this case with @angular/material@20.2.5)
- Had an animation at 06/10/2025, 9:50 UTC (with @angular/material@20.2.5 or @angular/material@20.2.7)
- Did not have an animation at 08/10/2025, 11:48 UTC (with @angular/material@20.2.7)
- Did have an animation at 10/10/2025, 12:19 UTC (with @angular/material@20.2.7)

I have also observed these changes in the examples in [https://material.angular.dev/components/sidenav/examples](https://material.angular.dev/components/sidenav/examples), which have suffered the same changes in animations in the same dates, but I cannot assure they have not changed the @angular/material version used.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:

- Create an Angular application that uses MatDrawer, install dependencies just once, and check how the drawer changes from having an animation to not having it in different dates.
- Or check how [https://material.angular.dev/components/sidenav/examples](https://material.angular.dev/components/sidenav/examples) changes from having an animation to not having it in different dates (in some cases without a release).

I know this is not easy to check if nobody else has noticed and it does not happen in the future (that would be fine). But if it happens again in the future, this will help resolve it.


### Expected Behavior

Angular Material changes behaviour only with a version change

### Actual Behavior

Angular Material changes behaviour without a version change

### Environment

- Angular: 20.3.3
- CDK/Material: 20.2.7
- Browser(s): Edge/Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular Material changes behaviour without a version change" (#32051)
